title.value: PROTEIN SEQUENCE AND STRUCTURE CO-DESIGN WITH EQUIVARIANT TRANSLATION
title.justification: The title of the paper is mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: P ROTEIN S EQUENCE AND S TRUCTURE C O -D ESIGN WITH E QUIVARIANT T RANSLATION

extractions.description: This paper introduces a novel method named PROTEIN SEQUENCE AND STRUCTURE CO-DESIGN WITH EQUIVARIANT TRANSLATION (PROTSEED) to co-design protein sequences and structures by iteratively translating both into a desirable state based on context features. The method incorporates a trigonometry-aware encoder and a roto-translation equivariant decoder to accelerate the inference process. Experimental results demonstrate that PROTSEED achieves state-of-the-art results across various protein design tasks while significantly improving inference times.

type.justification: The paper presents a new method, PROTSEED, and evaluates its performance against state-of-the-art baselines on multiple tasks with experimental data.
type.quote: Experimental results across multiple tasks show that our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines by a large margin

name.justification: The primary focus of the study is on designing protein sequences and structures, which falls under the domain of bioinformatics.
name.quote: Designing novel proteins with specific structures and desired functions has been a long-standing challenge in the field of bioengineering.

name.justification: The paper leverages deep learning techniques such as trigonometry-aware encoders and roto-translation equivariant decoders for protein design, classifying it within the machine learning domain.
name.quote: Existing approaches generate both protein sequence and structure using either autoregressive models or diffusion models... our model consists of a trigonometry-aware encoder... and a roto-translation equivariant decoder.

name.justification: The paper deals with the structural aspects of proteins, making this a subfield of focus.
name.quote: Our model consists of a trigonometry-aware encoder that reasons geometrical constraints and interactions from context features, and a roto-translation equivariant decoder that translates protein sequence and structure interdependently.

name.justification: The paper introduces the PROTSEED model for co-designing protein sequences and structures.
name.quote: In this paper, we propose a new method capable of protein sequence-structure equivariant co-design called P ROT S EED.

is_contributed.justification: The PROTSEED model is introduced and is a contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this paper, we propose a new method capable of protein sequence-structure equivariant co-design called P ROT S EED.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed as part of the experiments to demonstrate its performance.
is_executed.quote: Experimental results across multiple tasks show that our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines by a large margin

is_compared.justification: The model was compared against state-of-the-art baselines in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: Experimental results across multiple tasks show that our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines by a large margin

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary model introduced by the paper and thus has no referenced paper title.

name.justification: The Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) was used in the experiments as a source of data.
name.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) (Dunbar et al., 2014).

referenced_paper_title.value: Dunbar, J., Krawczyk, K., Leem, J., Baker, T., Fuchs, A., Georges, G., Shi, J., & Deane, C. M. (2014). Sabdab: the structural antibody database. Nucleic acids research, 42(D1), D1140-D1146.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) is referenced in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) (Dunbar et al., 2014).

name.justification: CATH was used as one of the benchmark datasets in experiments to evaluate the PROTSEED model.
name.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) (Dunbar et al., 2014) as well as two protein design benchmark data sets curated from CATH (Orengo et al., 1997).

referenced_paper_title.value: Orengo, C. A., Michie, A. D., Jones, S., Jones, D. T., Swindells, M. B., & Thornton, J. M. (1997). Cathâ€“a hierarchic classification of protein domain structures. Structure, 5(8), 1093-1109.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The CATH database is referenced in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) (Dunbar et al., 2014) as well as two protein design benchmark data sets curated from CATH (Orengo et al., 1997).

name.justification: The model is implemented in Pytorch, as mentioned in the appendix.
name.quote: P ROT S EED is implemented in Pytorch.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Pytorch is a widely used library in implementing machine learning models and thus has no specific referenced paper title.
